title: Grateful Dead Live at Ace's on 1975-01-00
lineage: Studio Master Reel -> ?-> Reel @7.5ips (TEAC A-4010 SL playback)-> Lexicon Lambda-> Logic 24/96 AIFF -> wav conversion to 16bit-44.1k-> xAct -> flac  (TRT: 22:12)

reviews.review_text: two or three keyboardists It's faint, but there are two, sometimes three keyboards. Check out at 20:10 or so - you hear acoustic piano and two electric pianos. My guess is that both Ned Lagin and Merl Saunders are on here.

just for argument's sake Doesn’t this music seem too far developed to be from Jan ’75?  The Feb 75 tapes are all pretty loose and jammy, and it seems odd that the band would be performing something this complicated on their first night back in the saddle.

Also, I don’t have McNally’s GD bio handy, but I believe he says that the first session at Ace’s was by a local band (not the GD) on the night of a full moon, which would have been Jan 27 or Feb 26.

The music is sweet, if you dig these rehearsal recordings, which I do.  Wish there was more!

track breakdown this one track consists of an extended jam with no vocals: 'Blues For Allah' > 'Sand Castles & Glass Camels' > 'King Solomon's Marbles' > 'Unusual Occurrences in the Desert'.

the rough timings (for the one track) would be:

00:00 tuning
00:39 Blues For Allah
03:59 Sand Castles & Glass Camels
08:44 King Solomon's Marbles (Part 1: Stronger Than Dirt)
13:45 King Solomon's Marbles (Part 2: Milkin' The Turkey)
15:48 King Solomon's Marbles (Part 1: Stronger Than Dirt)
16:57 King Solomon's Marbles (Part 1: Stronger Than Dirt)
17:26 King Solomon's Marbles (Part 2: Milkin' The Turkey)
20:31 Unusual Occurrences in the Desert
22:13 end

note: the start and end are faded in/out. that makes it difficult to determine where this fits in with the other tapes from that time.

I-) ihor

ace in the hole i’ve been living with this newly discovered reel for about a week now, savoring the sonic qualities/nuances of the music and the shifting rhythms, timbre, and texture of the piece. listening to the early explorations on themes that would make up the second side of the blues for allah LP, it’s easy to see why the record has been so near to my heart over the years.
this session documents the fertile period of exploration the band was engaged in during their “retirement.” in a larger sense, the dead’s choice of material for the album indicates that they were busily carving a unique path that no one expected.

the Music never Stops A  Gratitude and HUGE Thanks to All the Pioneers..in this cosmical soup extravagannza....Thank You to all the writers,Pioneers &Family  but also to the Great  "Sam Cutler" (for givin' these boys wings to fly Worldwide thru the Universe and StratosPhere)  -Truly-  the Music  Never Stops.......
Good Stuff Here Give it a spin.

Fun fun fun A lot of Grateful Dead fans may not realize that there is a treasure chest of Kick-Ass jamming in 1975, crystal clear, right to off the Soundboard stuff.

Not the GD's style of "musical deconstruction" improvisation that characterizes their 80's/90's shows.

This stuff is solid, funky and everyone there is really digging in.  This is a short recording but keep digging,

There are more as the years go on... they are called Ace Rehearsal

Check em out!!

Thanks to the hardcore papers that go to the work to track these recordings
